div1.p: Wheeler reports that she has found several items Peabody gave to the library.

div1.head: Letter from Helen Wheeler to Philip Showalter Hench, October 2, 1940
div1.opener:
THE JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
WELCH MEDICAL LIBRARY
1900 EAST MONUMENT STREET
BALTIMORE, MD.
October 2, 1940.
Dr. P. S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I am very sorry for the delay in replying to your letter of
September 18th.

We have only two items in our catalog which are listed as gifts
of Mr. Peabody: (1) his own pamphlet on the Conquest of Yellow Fever; and
(2) a collection of eight loose sheets including the yellow fever roll of
honor, final report of the Yellow Fever Committee, a letter from Mr. Peabody
“to the many friends of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Kissinger,” etc.

After extensive inquiry among staff members and others who were
here in the time of Dr. Garrison, we found two who knew that Mr. Peabody
had given some unbound material on yellow fever, but both of them stated
that Mr. Peabody had borrowed it back later on, and so far as they knew
he had never returned it. This was borne out by a memorandum in the gift
records dated February 15, 1935, and also by a letter from Dr. Garrison
to Mr. Peabody, written on that same date in response to Mr. Peabody's
letter of February 10th, saying that he was sending all the papers to Mr.
Peabody by express collect. Dr. Garrison died in April, 1935. There is
no further record on the subject, and we have been unable to find the
material among the uncataloged items in the vault. It looks as though Mr.
Peabody may still have it.

I have found the following items which may be of interest to you:
(1) a letter to Mr. Peabody from Herbert Lyman Clark describing his experi-
ence with the yellow fever epidemic in Jamaica in 1897; (2) a photostatic
copy of a letter from Walter Reed to Lieutenant Truby; and (3) an article
from the New York Herald of June 21, 1806. I am sending these three items,
together with the two mentioned above given by Mr. Peabody, to you by express
collect, and if any other material should come to light I shall be glad to
send it on immediately.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours Helen Wheeler.
For the Librarian HW
